title: Railway Station
description: The railway station was an example of decorated neoclassical architecture. The two-story building had a symmetrical plan, with the facade decorated with massive arched windows and a large pediment. Later, the station in the city of Kramatorsk was built to the same plan. The station building was significantly damaged by a missile attack, and the possibility of its restoration is unknown.

title: Tarnovsky House (Youth Library)
credits_after: Ministry of Internal Affairs of Ukraine
caption_before: Main façade of the Chernihiv youth library before the war
caption_after: The damaged building of Chernihiv youth library
description: The neo-Gothic one-story building of the Tarnovsky House initially functioned as a craft school for the nearby orphanage. Since 1902 the building housed a museum of Ukrainian antiquities – one of the first and most famous in Ukraine. In 1980 the building was repurposed into the Chernihiv Regional Library for Youth. After the Russian shelling, the building was heavily damaged, but due to its status as an architectural monument it was decided to restore it.

title: Drama Theatre
caption_before: Main façade of the Chernihiv Drama theater before the war
caption_after: Aerial view of the Chernihiv Drama theater after the strike
description: The Chernihiv Drama Theatre occupies a key place in the urban ensemble of one of the main squares of Chernihiv. The facade of the neoclassical building is decorated with many sculptures, and the building itself was built according to a design that was used in several cities in Ukraine. Since the rocket exploded above the building, its walls were not seriously damaged.

title: House of Officers
caption_before: Main façade of the House of Officers, 2008
caption_after: Aerial view of the House of Officers after the strike
description: The neoclassical Officers' House in Vinnytsia occupies an important place in the ensemble of the surrounding streets and terminates the perspective of Vinnytsia’s Kotsyubinsky Avenue. The building was already damaged during the Second World War, after which it was restored. In 2022, it was damaged again. Despite the fact that the building has been an architectural monument since 1997, local authorities initially did not want to restore it, wanting to build a shopping mall instead. Only a scandal involving the urban conservation community forced them to change their plans.

title: Bus Station
caption_before: Aerial view of the Bus station before the attack
caption_after: Ruins of the Bus Station on the Day of attack
description: The Dnipro Bus Station is an example of late modernism in Ukrainian architecture. In terms of design, it is the most complex bus station in all of Ukraine. The building had two levels of bus terminals, many administrative offices, and a hotel. The building was damaged by Russian shelling. Due to its young age, its architectural value is not publicly recognized, and it is unknown whether it will be restored.

title: Ice Sports Palace
architect: M. A. Aistov, Yu. A. Regentov, S. N. Badmaeva
caption_before: Ice Sports palace before the war
description: The Severodonetsk Ice Sports Palace was one of the largest structures of its kind in the USSR, accommodating up to 5,000 spectators. The building was multifunctional: it could be used as a sports arena, a concert hall, a cinema, and a congress palace. The various functions of the building were depicted in several mosaics decorating the corners of the façade. As a result of Russian shelling, the structures supporting the roof of the hall were damaged and the building collapsed.

title: Joseph Lev House on Zhylianska Street
caption_before: Josehp Lev house before the war
description: This residential building on Zhylianska Street was built by the Jewish merchant Joseph Lev. The building's architecture is based on the popular brick style of the turn of the 19th and 20th centuries. This building was the first historical building in Kyiv to be damaged as a result of the Russian attack. Despite a petition from city residents for a restoration, city authorities are unwilling to restore it.

title: Zaporozhstal Factory House
caption_before: Zaporozhstal factory house before the war
caption_after: Zaporozhstal factory house on the day of attack
description: The residential building of the Zaporizhstal plant is one of the key elements of the architectural ensemble of Soborny Avenue. Its facade is faced with ceramic tiles and richly decorated with architectural elements recalling the Renaissance. The restoration of the building after the Russian missile strike became a unique example of careful treatment of architectural monuments. During the ongoing reconstruction, the technology for ceramic tiles and decoration production has been used for the first time since the 1950s to recreate the lost decorations.

title: Kahovska Power Plant
caption_before: Aerial view of the Kahovska power plant machine hall before the war
caption_after: Ruins of the demolished Kahovska power plant
description: The machine hall of the Kakhovka hydroelectric power station was incredibly exquisite in architectural terms. Its façade featured Renaissance-revival architectural techniques, while the round porthole windows referred to both the Bauhaus and the rose windows of the Gothic era. As a result of the blowing up of the hydroelectric power station by Russian troops, the machine hall fell apart into several pieces and cannot be restored.

title: DniproHES Machine Hall
caption_before: DniproHES machine hall before the war
caption_after: Inside the ruined DniproHES machine hall
description: The Dnieper Hydroelectric Power Plant's turbine hall was an interesting example of Soviet Constructivist architecture which recalls the modernism of the Bauhaus School. The building was faced with Armenian tuff. Many of the original design elements were preserved here, and the turbine hall was planned to be nominated for UNESCO World Heritage Site status.

title: Lysychansk Gymnasium
description: The building of the Lysychansk Gymnasium (secondary school) is part of the unique ensemble of the Belgian architectural heritage. Initially, there were barracks for 170 people, later - a hospital, and later - the Gymnasium. The building was listed as a monument and preserved in its original condition until 2022.

title: Palace of Engineers and Technicians
architect: Vladyslav Fadeichev, Boris Dzbanovskyi, Yevhen Ivanov
description: The neoclassical building of the Palace of Engineers and Technicians won first place at the All-Ukrainian Competition for New Buildings in 1953. Its classicist architecture with the appropriate sculptural elements made it one of the most iconic buildings of the city. It was known for the high quality of the interior design on par with the famous government buildings in Kyiv.

title: Kostyantynivka City Administration
description: The building of the Kostiantynivka city administration was originally built as a hotel. Its main facade was oriented towards the railway, as the main city thoroughfare. The building went through a number of renovations, being originally built to a constructivist architectural style, with classical decorative elements later enriching the facade, finally being covered in tile.

title: Kharkiv Regional Administration
description: The Kharkiv Regional Administration building is a reconstruction of a constructivist building designed by architect Steinberg in the 1930s. During the reconstruction, the facade design was changed to neoclassical—the new look given to the whole square. The building is richly decorated with classical elements. After being hit by two missiles, the building was badly damaged, but the public is fighting for its restoration.

title: Mykolaiv Regional Administration
description: The building of the Mykolaiv regional administration became the final element to the ensemble of the central square of the city. Designed in the modernist style, it had a clearly expressed vertical rhythm, echoing the city council building located opposite. The interior of the building contained many monumental art elements. The missile strike completely pierced the central part of the building, and thus its restoration is not considered possible.

title: Housing for Polytechnicians
description: The residential complex at Striyska street was built in the style of early functionalism. The floor plate arranged around a central courtyard makes for a quiet, enclosed space. The complex was mostly settled by the workers of the Lviv Polytechnic. The restoration of the building began immediately after the missile attack and is mostly finished.

title: Spaso-Preobrazhensky Cathedral
description: The Spaso-Preobrazhensky (Transfiguration of the Savior) Cathedral was built as the main city church. The neoclassical building was located on a city square and served as the focal point of several streets. Its interior and exterior were richly decorated. After the destruction of the original church in 1936, it was restored in the late 20th century.

title: St. George Church
caption_after: The fire that destroyed the church
description: St. George church in the village of Zavorychi was built in 1873. This single-domed wooden church represented the architectural trends of late 19th century. The church survived during the Second World War and the Soviet Era, though in 1935 it was closed and turned it into a grain store.

title: Church of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary
description: Church of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary was listed as a monument of national importance. It was one of the best examples of wooden architecture in the region, with its dome resembling neoclassical architecture. The church survived the duration of the Soviet Union including the Second World War, but was ruined by the Russian strike.

title: House of Abrasive Plant Workers
description: These apartments for workers in the abrasives plant were built as a part of larger urban ensemble of Soborny Avenue. Its architecture is consistent with a number of buildings along the avenue. The decision was made to restore the destroyed section, although it is not known whether the original architectural appearance will feature in the restoration, as the building was not listed for historical protection.

title: Drama Theatre
description: The Mariupol Drama Theatre was located on the axis of the city’s central avenue. Although this blueprint had already been used elsewhere, the facade had an unique design incorporating sculptural compositions. The air attack on the theatre caused numerous casualties among the people who used it as a shelter. The occupation authorities have started to restore it in its original form.

title: House with the Clock
caption_before: House with a clock before the war
description: The House with the Clock was one of Mariupol’s most iconic buildings. The clock on the façade was a landmark and the corner underneath it was known as a common meeting-place. The tower housed the studio of the famous artist Viktor Arnautov. The occupiers did not repair the damaged building, opting instead to demolish it for new construction on the same site.

title: Railway Station
caption_before: Railway station on the old postard, 1980-s
description: The railway station building was typical of the modernist era. Its interior was decorated with a grand mosaic panel "Metallurgists" by Valentin Konstantinov and Lel Kuzminkov. The building's façade was later re-clad. After damage in 2022, the building was not restored, but demolished, and a new one, similar to the old, was built. The mosaics were lost.

title: Railway Technical School (Former City Hall)
description: The building of the former city hall was one of the most elegant in old Bakhmut. The three-storey building, 90 meters wide, was built in the Neo-Renaissance style. The entire Donetsk region was managed from here in 1920-1924. Later, the building housed the railway administration, and since 1955 the railway technical school. In 2022, the building completely burned down as a result of shelling.

title: Center for Children and Youth (Former Bank)
description: This was one of the first bank buildings in the city. It has some art nouveau features, including floral ornaments. In the course of history, the building served as a pedagogical technical school, a teacher's institute, a high school and a children's and youth center. As a result of Russian shelling, the building was completely burned down.

title: Residential House on Myru 42
description: The art deco building at 42 Myru Street forms part of the architectural ensemble of the central square. Its rounded facade compositionally reflects the same roundness of the facade of the building across from it. As a result of the damage, the building lost its inner walls, and its condition is worse than it was after the damage in the Second World War.

title: Railway Station
description: The railway station building was built in 1912-1913. Its original appearance had features of Art Nouveau architecture. After its destruction in 1943, the station was rebuilt on top of the old foundation, but followed instead the neoclassical style, along with significant changes to the central volume. Since 2004, the station has had a protected status, but this did not prevent its facade from being distorted by composite panels. The building is now destroyed to a much greater extent.

title: Regional Library
description: The design of the Oles Honchar Regional Library was based on an improvement of an earlier project. It was located on a picturesque slope near the bank of the Dnieper river. Its valuable modernist interior was especially cherished but was lost as a result of shelling.

title: Yuvileyniy Concert Hall
description: The Yuvileyniy Film and Concert Hall is a modernist landmark of Kherson. Its design was adapted from an existing plan, first implemented in Kharkiv in 1957. This is one of the very few modernist buildings to have the status of a protected architectural monument.

title: Maritime Academy
description: The Maritime Academy in Kherson was founded in the days of the Russian Empire. The Academy is a complex, comprised of a number of buildings, built at different times and in different styles. One of the most expressive was a corner neoclassical building with an emphasized cylindrical volume. Shelling left the left wing of the building completely ruined.

title: Palace of Labour
caption_before: Palace of Labour on the old postcard
description: The neoclassical building, originally built by the insurance company “Russia”, occupies almost an entire block and combines residential apartments, retail and office space. During the Soviet era, it housed various institutions, including the Palace of Labor. The building is richly decorated with sculptures, including the central sculptural group, ironically titled "Mercy of Russia", which miraculously survived the Russian shelling.

title: Palace of Culture of the Railway Workers
description: The Palace of Culture of the Railway Workers was one of the most striking examples of constructivist architecture in Kharkiv. Its façade was divided geometrically with prominent glazing in monumental scale. The interior was richly decorated with frescoes by Yevgeny Lanceray. Though the building had been preserved in almost its original form, it was damaged in an airstrike.

title: Maslovsky's Apartment Building
description: Maslovsky's apartment house was built in the Art Nouveau style. The house retained its lavishly decorated main staircase and vestibule with an authentic wooden door. Despite minor changes to the exterior, the Art Nouveau interior was preserved. A projectile impact destroyed the entire central part of the building.

title: Palace of Culture
architect: Mark Bubnov, Vadim Davidenko, Ilya Bylinkin
description: The City Palace of Culture was the largest cultural space in Lozova. It was constructed according to a a standard design. Before the war, the building was restored. Despite a direct missile hit, its restoration remains possible.

title: Railway Station
caption_after: Remains of station after a direct hit
description: The one-story building of the railway station had been preserved since the railway first appeared in the city. It was a typical example of railway architecture of those years. The building survived World War II and was restored in the interim. A direct hit during Russian shelling, however, left nothing to be restored.

title: Skovoroda Museum
description: The museum of the Ukrainian philosopher Skovoroda located in the Kovalivsky estate is one of the oldest buildings to have suffered damage during the Russian-Ukrainian war. Though a direct missile hit damaged the building, a significant part of the exhibits were saved through prompt evacuation. Plans to restore the museum have been announced.

title: Residential House on Vokzalna Square
description: The residential building on Vokzalna Square was one of the most important elements of the square's neoclassical architectural ensemble. Originally planned with a high tower, it sits at the terminus of city’s central avenue. A missile strike on the building destroyed its top floor.

title: Residential House on Marat Street
description: The residential building at 13 Marata Street was a part of an ensemble of four buildings, with three of the four built in the 1950s. Despite its overall modesty, the facade was adorned with a number of neoclassical decorations. After a missile strike, several sections of the building were destroyed. Residents want the building to be restored, but city authorities doubt this is possible.

title: Okhmadyt Children's Hospital
caption_before: Old photo of the building, early XX century
description: The children's hospital was built during the Russian Empire with funds from philanthropist Nikola Tereshchenko. The missile's impact on the hospital building was one of the most famous and egregious cases of a strike on civilian infrastructure during Russian-Ukrainian war. Despite non-critical damage and many donations, it is unknown whether the historic building will be restored.

title: Palace of Culture
description: Irpin's Palace of Culture was built by order of the Bucha brick factory. It was the city's most monumental building, decorated with sculpture and neoclassical decorations. As a result of the shelling, the building was damaged, and there is an ongoing discussion about the possibility of its restoration.
